summary: This document is a chain of emails from August 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing Touhy requests (requests for government information) related to Jeffrey Epstein. The emails focus on processing requests from victims/plaintiffs in civil suits, concerns about Giglio disclosures, coordination with other districts, and the identification of a victim as Maria Lacerda.

persons.name: John McEnany
persons.context: A prosecutor in the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office involved in reviewing and advising on Touhy requests related to the Epstein case, expressing concerns about Giglio disclosures.

persons.name: Steven Kochevar
persons.context: The point person in the Civil Division handling Touhy requests from Epstein victims/plaintiffs, drafting response letters and coordinating with the criminal team.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: A prosecutor on the criminal side discussing the theory behind Giglio disclosures and coordinating with the civil division on victim requests.

persons.name: David Jones
persons.context: A prosecutor copied on emails discussing Touhy request procedures and approvals.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney for a victim/plaintiff in a civil suit against Epstein's estate, who made a Touhy request for information.

persons.name: Maria Lacerda
persons.context: Identified in an email as a Jane Doe victim/plaintiff who is making a Touhy request; previously involved in immunity discussions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the investigation; the subject of the Touhy requests from victims seeking information for civil litigation.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.context: Mentioned as the 'responsible' U.S. Attorney who might receive a referred Touhy subpoena from another district.

persons.name: Sarah
persons.context: Referred to as a 'wiser Touhy head' in the civil division to consult on procedural questions.

persons.name: Jeffrey
persons.context: Mentioned briefly as someone John McEnany spoke to about designating Steven Kochevar as the point of contact for Touhy requests.

persons.name: Rossmiller
persons.context: Mentioned in draft Touhy language as the initial recipient of a request for information.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Mentioned as having signed off on a Touhy response letter and document production.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Mentioned as having signed off on a Touhy response letter and document production.

connections.description: Colleagues in the U.S. Attorney's Office coordinating on legal strategy and approvals for Touhy requests related to the Epstein case.
Prosecutors from the criminal and civil divisions, respectively, working together to handle victim requests and disclosure issues.
Kaplan is the attorney representing victim Maria Lacerda in civil litigation against Epstein's estate, as indicated by the Touhy request.
McEnany is a prosecutor handling information requests from Lacerda, a victim/witness, and considering Giglio implications.
Kochevar, as the government's point of contact, corresponds with Kaplan regarding her client's Touhy request for documents.

events.title: Giglio Disclosure Concern Raised
events.description: John McEnany emails the team stating that Touhy communications with a victim (VB) are probably disclosable as Giglio information (information affecting a witness's credibility).

events.title: Touhy Response to Epstein Victim Approved
events.description: Steven Kochevar sends an updated response letter to a Touhy request from an Epstein victim, noting the Maxwell defense team has signed off on it.

events.title: Identification of Jane Doe as Maria Lacerda
events.description: John McEnany confirms in an email that 'Jane Doe' in a Touhy request is Maria Lacerda, a victim involved in prior immunity discussions.

events.title: Establishment of Touhy Request Process
events.description: Email chain establishes Steven Kochevar as the point person for Touhy requests from Epstein victims, with a draft letter outlining the formal request process.

keyFacts: Prosecutors expressed concern that complying with a victim's Touhy request could be construed as conferring a 'benefit' and thus be disclosable as Giglio material, potentially affecting the witness's credibility.
A victim making a Touhy request is identified as Maria Lacerda, who was previously involved in immunity discussions during the Florida investigation.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for SDNY possessed FBI investigative files from the S.D. Fla. investigation but deliberately avoided obtaining files from the S.D. Fla. U.S. Attorney's Office due to conflict and discovery issues.
The emails reveal coordination and sometimes tension between the criminal and civil divisions of the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office on how to handle victim requests for investigation materials.
The Maxwell defense team was consulted and signed off on the government's response to at least one victim's Touhy request.
